hints_html:
Strap on your seal belts. We’re going to need a lot of applications of the chain rule. If \(h(x) = f(g(x))\) for differentiable f and g, then the chain rule states that

\(\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\)

To help us out we should break the problem down into smaller subproblems. Let \(f_{1}(x) = x^{5}\) and let \(f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2))\). Then \(y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^5(\cos(3x^2))\). So the derivative by the chain rule is

\(\displaystyle y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x)\)

To solve for the derivative of \(f_{2}(x)\) we again use the chain rule...

$f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2))$. Then
$y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^5(\cos(3x^2))$. So the derivative by the
chain rule is

$\displaystyle y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x)$

To solve for the derivative of $f_{2}(x)$ we again use the chain rule...
hints_raw:
Strap on your seal belts. We're going to need a lot of applications of the chain rule.  If <math> h(x) = f(g(x)) </math> for differentiable ''f'' and ''g'', then the chain rule states that

<math> \displaystyle
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)
</math>
To help us out we should break the problem down into smaller subproblems. Let <math>f_{1}(x) = x^{5} </math> and let <math> f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2)) </math>. Then <math> y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^5(\cos(3x^2))</math>. So the derivative by the chain rule is 

<math>\displaystyle  y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x) </math>

To solve for the derivative of <math> f_{2}(x) </math> we again use the chain rule...
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
Let \(\displaystyle f_{1}(x) = x^{5}\) and let \(\displaystyle f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2))\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^{5}(\cos(3x^2)).\end{aligned}\]

So the derivative by the chain rule is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x)\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 1)

Now, \(\displaystyle f'_{1}(x) = 5x^{4}\) and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = 5(\sin(\cos(3x^2)))^{4} = 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 2)

For \(\displaystyle f'_{2}(x)\), we again use the chain rule. Let \(\displaystyle f_{3}(x) = \sin(x)\) and \(\displaystyle f_{4}(x) = \cos(3x^{2})\) so we have that \(\displaystyle f_{2}(x) = f_{3}(f_{4}(x))\). Using the chain rule, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{2}(x) = f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 3)

Notice that \(\displaystyle f_{3}'(x) = \cos(x)\) and thus

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{3}(f_{4}(x)) = \cos(\cos(3x^{2}))\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 4)

Thus it suffices to find \(\displaystyle f'_{4}(x)\). Guess what we’re going to use... the chain rule! Let \(\displaystyle f_{5}(x) = \cos(x)\) and \(\displaystyle f_{6}(x) = 3x^{2}\). Then, the chain rule states that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x)\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 5)

Now, \(\displaystyle f'_{5}(x) = -\sin(x)\) and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{5}(f_{6}(x)) = -\sin(3x^{2})\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 6)

Here, the derivative of \(\displaystyle f_{6}(x)\) is actually doable! We have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{6}(x) = \frac{d}{dx}(3x^{2}) = 6x\end{aligned}\]

and hence by Equations 5 and 6, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x) = (-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x)\end{aligned}\]

(Equation 7)

Combining Equations 1,2,3,4,6 and 7, we have

\[\begin{aligned} y' &= f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x) && \text{(via Equation 1)}\\ &= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)) && \text{(via Equation 2 and 3)}\\ &= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))(-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x))) && \text{(via Equation 4 and 7)}\\ &= -30x\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))\sin(3x^{2})) \end{aligned}\]

Phew!
sols_latex:
Let $\displaystyle f_{1}(x) = x^{5}$ and let
$\displaystyle f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2))$. Then

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^{5}(\cos(3x^2)).
\end{align*}

So the derivative by the chain rule is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle  y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x)
\end{align*} (Equation 1)

Now, $\displaystyle f'_{1}(x) = 5x^{4}$ and so

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = 5(\sin(\cos(3x^2)))^{4} = 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))
\end{align*}
(Equation 2)

For $\displaystyle f'_{2}(x)$, we again use the chain rule. Let
$\displaystyle f_{3}(x) = \sin(x)$ and
$\displaystyle f_{4}(x) = \cos(3x^{2})$ so we have that
$\displaystyle f_{2}(x) = f_{3}(f_{4}(x))$. Using the chain rule, we
have that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{2}(x) = f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)
\end{align*} (Equation 3)

Notice that $\displaystyle f_{3}'(x) = \cos(x)$ and thus

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{3}(f_{4}(x)) = \cos(\cos(3x^{2}))
\end{align*} (Equation 4)

Thus it suffices to find $\displaystyle f'_{4}(x)$. Guess what we're
going to use... the chain rule! Let $\displaystyle f_{5}(x) = \cos(x)$
and $\displaystyle f_{6}(x) = 3x^{2}$. Then, the chain rule states that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x)
\end{align*} (Equation 5)

Now, $\displaystyle f'_{5}(x) = -\sin(x)$ and so

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{5}(f_{6}(x)) = -\sin(3x^{2})
\end{align*} (Equation 6)

Here, the derivative of $\displaystyle f_{6}(x)$ is actually doable! We
have that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{6}(x) = \frac{d}{dx}(3x^{2}) = 6x
\end{align*}

and hence by Equations 5 and 6, we have

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x) = (-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x)
\end{align*}
(Equation 7)

Combining Equations 1,2,3,4,6 and 7, we have

\begin{align*}
y' &= f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x) && \text{(via Equation 1)}\\
&= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)) && \text{(via Equation 2 and 3)}\\
&= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))(-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x))) && \text{(via Equation 4 and 7)}\\
&= -30x\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))\sin(3x^{2})) 
\end{align*}

Phew!
sols_raw:
Let <math>\displaystyle f_{1}(x) = x^{5} </math> and let <math>\displaystyle f_{2}(x) = \sin(\cos(3x^2)) </math>. Then 

:<math>\displaystyle y = f_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = \sin^{5}(\cos(3x^2)) </math>. 

So the derivative by the chain rule is 

:<math>\displaystyle  y' = f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x) </math> (Equation 1)

Now, <math> \displaystyle f'_{1}(x) = 5x^{4} </math> and so

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{1}(f_{2}(x)) = 5(\sin(\cos(3x^2)))^{4} = 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))</math> (Equation 2)

For <math> \displaystyle f'_{2}(x)</math>, we again use the chain rule. Let <math> \displaystyle f_{3}(x) = \sin(x)</math> and <math> \displaystyle f_{4}(x) = \cos(3x^{2})</math> so we have that <math> \displaystyle f_{2}(x) = f_{3}(f_{4}(x))</math>. Using the chain rule, we have that 

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{2}(x) = f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)</math> (Equation 3)

Notice that <math> \displaystyle f_{3}'(x) = \cos(x)</math> and thus

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{3}(f_{4}(x)) = \cos(\cos(3x^{2}))</math> (Equation 4)

Thus it suffices to find <math> \displaystyle f'_{4}(x) </math>. Guess what we're going to use... the chain rule! Let <math> \displaystyle f_{5}(x) = \cos(x)</math> and <math> \displaystyle f_{6}(x) = 3x^{2}</math>. Then, the chain rule states that

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x)</math> (Equation 5)

Now, <math> \displaystyle f'_{5}(x) = -\sin(x)</math> and so

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{5}(f_{6}(x)) = -\sin(3x^{2})</math> (Equation 6)

Here, the derivative of <math> \displaystyle f_{6}(x)</math> is actually doable! We have that

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{6}(x) = \frac{d}{dx}(3x^{2}) = 6x</math>

and hence by Equations 5 and 6, we have

:<math> \displaystyle f'_{4}(x) = f'_{5}(f_{6}(x))f'_{6}(x) = (-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x) </math> (Equation 7)

Combining Equations 1,2,3,4,6 and 7, we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
y' &= f'_{1}(f_{2}(x))f_{2}'(x) && \text{(via Equation 1)}\\
&= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(f'_{3}(f_{4}(x))f_{4}'(x)) && \text{(via Equation 2 and 3)}\\
&= 5\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))(\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))(-\sin(3x^{2}))(6x))) && \text{(via Equation 4 and 7)}\\
&= -30x\sin^{4}(\cos(3x^2))\cos(\cos(3x^{2}))\sin(3x^{2})) 
\end{align}
</math>

Phew!
statement_raw:
{{Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2010/Question 1/Statement/Header}}

Find the derivative of
:<math>\displaystyle
y=\sin^5(\cos(3x^2))
</math>
